title: 107_s421
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2001". The Congress finds that gifted and talented students demonstrate high performance in specific academic fields and require specialized services to fully develop their capabilities. These students come from diverse backgrounds and are often underrepresented in gifted education programs due to their advanced academic abilities. The students with special educational needs require unique opportunities not typically available in regular education programs. Parents play a crucial role in developing appropriate services for gifted students. There is no federal mandate to identify or serve the approximately 3,000,000 gifted students in the nation. Some states and local agencies are taking steps to address this issue. Some states and local agencies allocate resources to educate gifted and talented students, while others do not. Varying state laws and funding mechanisms result in disparities in services for this special-needs population. It is crucial for the United States to have more students achieving at higher levels, especially highly capable students who need education to excel in today's innovative and creative workplace. The performance of twelfth-grade advanced students in the US on international assessments like TIMSS has been among the lowest globally. The performance of gifted and talented students in the United States, as shown in the TIMSS study, was among the lowest globally in physics and advanced mathematics. Elementary school gifted students already master a significant portion of the curriculum before the school year begins. Funding for challenging programs for gifted students is minimal. The purpose of the Act is to provide grants to support programs for gifted students. The Act aims to provide funding for programs and services for gifted students in elementary and secondary schools to meet their educational needs. The Act authorizes programs and activities for gifted students in elementary and secondary schools. The Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies for developing gifted education programs and providing educational services and materials. This includes inservice training programs for educators and making materials available through various entities. The Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies for developing gifted education programs, providing direct educational services to gifted students, supporting innovative approaches and curricula, and offering challenging coursework through new technologies. State educational agencies can use up to 10 percent of funds for peer review process, supervision of fund awards, planning and processing of funds, monitoring and evaluation of programs under the Act. The State educational agency can use up to 10 percent of funds for various activities under the Act, including dissemination of program information, creating a State gifted education advisory board, and providing technical assistance. Additionally, not more than 2 percent of the total amount received can be used to educate and support parents and caregivers of gifted children in participating in educational decisions. SEC. 4. ALLOTMENT TO STATES. The Secretary reserves funds for teacher training in Bureau of Indian Affairs schools. States receive funding based on the number of children aged 5-18, with a minimum allotment set. If a State does not apply for funding, the Secretary will reallot the amount to other States based on the same criteria. SEC. 5. STATE APPLICATIONS. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. The application must include assurances of the agency's responsibility for program administration, ability to provide matching funds, and use of funds to support gifted and talented students. The State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with required information to receive funds for gifted and talented students. Funds must supplement, not replace, state and local funds for specialized education. The State must develop program assessment models for accountability. The Secretary will approve applications meeting the requirements. SEC. 6. DISTRIBUTION TO LOCAL EDUCATIONAL AGENCIES.

A State educational agency must allocate at least 88 percent of funds to local educational agencies through competitive grants to support programs for gifted students. Grants should meet the needs of the students served.

SEC. 7. LOCAL APPLICATIONS. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a local educational agency must submit an application to the State educational agency. The application must include assurances on how the funds will be used to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, how educational needs will be met, and how personnel will be trained in educating gifted students. The local educational agency must assure that funds received will supplement, not replace, existing funds for the education of gifted and talented students. SEC. 8. Competitive grants to states are awarded on a competitive basis to State educational agencies to implement activities described in section 3. SEC. 9. Reporting requires State educational agencies to submit annual reports on students served and activities supported. SEC. 10. Definitions are provided. "In this Act, the term 'gifted and talented' is defined based on applicable State law or by the State educational agency or local educational agency if the State does not have a specific law defining the term." The terms defined in the Act include "local educational agency," "Secretary," and "State," with references to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is set at $160,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006.
